articles.headline: 2 Senators Strike Deal on Health Subsidies That Trump Cut Off
articles.snippet: A plan by Senators Lamar Alexander of Tennessee and Patty Murray of Washington to fund health subsidies for low-income consumers won President Trump’s backing.
articles.abstract: A plan by Senators Lamar Alexander of Tennessee and Patty Murray of Washington to fund health subsidies for low-income consumers won President Trump’s backing.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two leading senators, hoping to stabilize teetering health insurance markets under the Affordable Care Act, reached a bipartisan deal on Tuesday to fund critical subsidies to insurers that President Trump moved just days ago to cut off.
articles.byline: By Thomas Kaplan and Robert Pear

articles.headline: Xi Jinping Opens China’s Party Congress, His Hold Tighter Than Ever
articles.snippet: Warning of deep and complicated changes but describing the outlook as “extremely bright,” the president is set to make himself the indispensable man.
articles.abstract: Warning of deep and complicated changes but describing the outlook as “extremely bright,” the president is set to make himself the indispensable man.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When Xi Jinping strode out in the Great Hall of the People five years ago as China’s new leader, his tight smile barely hid the atmosphere of smoldering crisis.

articles.headline: George Soros Transfers Billions to Open Society Foundations
articles.snippet: Mr. Soros has moved about $18 billion to Open Society, the charity he founded which promotes human rights around the world. He plans to give still more.
articles.abstract: Mr. Soros has moved about $18 billion to Open Society, the charity he founded which promotes human rights around the world. He plans to give still more.
articles.lead_paragraph: George Soros, the billionaire hedge fund manager and a major Democratic donor, has given $18 billion to his Open Society Foundations, one of the largest transfers of wealth ever made by a private donor to a single foundation.

articles.headline: Google Serves Fake News Ads in an Unlikely Place: Fact-Checking Sites
articles.snippet: Google placed ads linking to blatantly bogus stories on Snopes and PolitiFact, sites created precisely to dispel such falsehoods.
articles.abstract: Google placed ads linking to blatantly bogus stories on Snopes and PolitiFact, sites created precisely to dispel such falsehoods.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The headlines are eye-catching. Melania Trump is leaving the White House! Home renovation cable star Joanna Gaines has abandoned her HGTV show and husband Chip Gaines! Televangelist Joel Osteen is leaving his wife!
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Linda Qiu

articles.headline: Navy SEALs Were Ready if Pakistan Failed to Free Family Held as Hostages
articles.snippet: American officials asked Pakistan to rescue an American woman, her Canadian husband and their children. With new intelligence on their whereabouts, officials had limited time to act.
articles.abstract: American officials asked Pakistan to rescue an American woman, her Canadian husband and their children. With new intelligence on their whereabouts, officials had limited time to act.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A C.I.A. drone was circling a remote valley in northwest Pakistan last month when it picked up an unusual sight: a young woman and children in a militant camp. To intelligence analysts, she appeared to be an American abducted five years earlier while backpacking in Afghanistan with her Canadian husband.
articles.byline: By Adam Goldman and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Women Denounce Harassment in California’s Capital
articles.snippet: Women complained of groping, lewd comments and suggestions of trading sexual favors for legislation in Sacramento.
articles.abstract: Women complained of groping, lewd comments and suggestions of trading sexual favors for legislation in Sacramento.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The groundswell over sexual harassment that has rocked Hollywood moved into California’s capital on Tuesday as more than 140 women — including legislators, senior legislative aides and lobbyists — came forward to denounce what they describe as pervasive sexual misconduct by powerful men in the nation’s most influential legislature.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Jennifer Medina

articles.headline: A Marine Attacked an Iraqi Restaurant. But Was It a Hate Crime or PTSD?
articles.snippet: After a Marine attacked an Iraqi restaurant in Portland, Ore., his family said he was provoked by trauma, not hate, and that he needed help, not jail time.
articles.abstract: After a Marine attacked an Iraqi restaurant in Portland, Ore., his family said he was provoked by trauma, not hate, and that he needed help, not jail time.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — The DarSalam Iraqi restaurant, with its steaming plates of falafel and kebab, has for years served as a popular community gathering spot here. The Iraqi family who ran it felt welcome in this eclectic city.

articles.headline: How the Frightful Five Put Start-Ups in a Lose-Lose Situation
articles.snippet: In Silicon Valley, small companies used to unseat big ones. Now the clutches of the five biggest tech companies are hard to escape.
articles.abstract: In Silicon Valley, small companies used to unseat big ones. Now the clutches of the five biggest tech companies are hard to escape.
articles.lead_paragraph: The tech giants are too big. But so what? Hasn’t that always been the case?

articles.headline: With Loss of Its Caliphate, ISIS May Return to Guerrilla Roots
articles.snippet: With the fall of its capital and loss of territory, the Islamic State may be reeling but not vanquished.
articles.abstract: With the fall of its capital and loss of territory, the Islamic State may be reeling but not vanquished.
articles.lead_paragraph: Its de facto capital is falling. Its territory has shriveled from the size of Portugal to a handful of outposts. Its surviving leaders are on the run.
articles.byline: By Margaret Coker, Eric Schmitt and Rukmini Callimachi

articles.headline: In Italian Schools, Reading, Writing and Recognizing Fake News
articles.snippet: A new program, aided by companies like Facebook, will aim to teach students how to recognize and stop the sharing of fake news and conspiracy theories.
articles.abstract: A new program, aided by companies like Facebook, will aim to teach students how to recognize and stop the sharing of fake news and conspiracy theories.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — After reading the horrors in Dante’s “Inferno,” Italian students will soon turn to the dangers of the digital age. While juggling math assignments, they’ll also tackle work sheets prepared by reporters from the national broadcaster RAI. And separate from the weekly hour of religion, they will receive a list of what amounts to a new set of Ten Commandments.

articles.headline: Trump’s Condolence Call to Soldier’s Widow Ignites an Imbroglio
articles.snippet: A furious back-and-forth turned what can be an emotionally wrenching encounter into an ugly spectacle between the president and a bereaved citizen.
articles.abstract: A furious back-and-forth turned what can be an emotionally wrenching encounter into an ugly spectacle between the president and a bereaved citizen.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s condolence call to the widow of a slain soldier exploded into a vicious row that swamped the White House on Wednesday, with the soldier’s grieving mother accusing the president of disrespecting her family and a defiant Mr. Trump complaining that his words had been cynically twisted for political purposes.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Yamiche Alcindor

articles.headline: Trump Pulls Back From Senate Deal to Fund Health Subsidies
articles.snippet: After voicing support, the president offered a different take on the plan, while its Republican architect predicted it would pass before the end of the year.
articles.abstract: After voicing support, the president offered a different take on the plan, while its Republican architect predicted it would pass before the end of the year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Wednesday backed away from his endorsement of a bipartisan Senate proposal to stabilize health insurance markets, throwing the legislative effort into doubt even as the chief architect of the deal predicted that it would become law before the end of the year.
articles.byline: By Thomas Kaplan and Robert Pear
